Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation2: A transit authority superviO35r has just entered the cabin for an immediate and unannounced performance audit.
Story: I glance at my phone during a brief stop, a message from my spouse lighting up the screen: “Can you please fold the laundry tonight? It’s piling up.” I picture the overflowing basket in the corner of our bedroom, the silent expectation that I’ll help keep our home running smoothly. But before I can reply, the cabin door slides open and my supervisor steps in, clipboard in hand, eyes sharp. “Unannounced audit,” he says, settling into the jump seat. My heart rate spikes. I know every move I make will be scrutinized—my announcements, my timing, my adherence to every protocol. I can’t afford a single mistake. Yet, in the back of my mind, the image of the laundry persists, tangled with guilt and frustration. I want to be reliable at home, to share the load, but right now, every ounce of my focus must be on the tracks ahead and the supervisor beside me. The train lurches forward, and I feel myself pulled in two directions, the weight of both roles pressing down, waiting for me to choose which expectation I’ll meet first.
